slides.title: Welcome to Chemical Engineering
slides.content:
# Introduction to Chemical Engineering

Welcome to **Chemical Engineering** - transforming materials!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Process Design** - Industrial systems
- **Mass and Energy Balances** - Conservation principles
- **Reaction Engineering** - Chemical reactions
- **Separations** - Purifying products
- **Transport Phenomena** - Mass, heat, momentum

> **Fun Fact:** Chemical engineers make everything from medicine to fuel to food!

slides.title: Mass Balance
slides.content:
# Mass Balance

## Conservation of Mass:
```
Input = Output + Accumulation
```

## For Steady State:
```
Input = Output
```

## General Approach:
1. Draw process flowsheet
2. Identify streams and components
3. Write balance equations
4. Solve for unknowns

## Types:
- Overall balance (all components)
- Component balance (single species)

## Units:
- kg/s, lb/hr, mol/min, etc.

slides.title: Energy Balance
slides.content:
# Energy Balance

## First Law:
```
Q - W = delta_H + delta_KE + delta_PE
```

## Simplified (no work, negligible KE/PE):
```
Q = delta_H
```

## Enthalpy:
- Sensible heat: H = m x Cp x delta_T
- Latent heat: H = m x delta_H_vap
- Heat of reaction: delta_H_rxn

## Reference States:
- Elements at 25C, 1 atm
- Consistent basis required

## Heat of Formation:
- Energy to form compound from elements

slides.title: Unit Operations
slides.content:
# Unit Operations

## Definition:
Basic steps in chemical processing.

## Categories:

| Category | Examples |
|----------|----------|
| Fluid flow | Pumping, piping |
| Heat transfer | Exchangers, boilers |
| Mass transfer | Distillation, absorption |
| Reactions | Reactors |
| Mechanical | Mixing, size reduction |

## Process Flow Diagram (PFD):
- Shows major equipment
- Stream flows
- Operating conditions

slides.title: Reaction Kinetics
slides.content:
# Reaction Kinetics

## Reaction Rate:
```
r_A = -dC_A/dt
```
Rate of disappearance of reactant A.

## Rate Law:
```
r = k x [A]^n x [B]^m
```
- k = rate constant
- n, m = reaction orders

## Temperature Effect:
Arrhenius equation:
```
k = A x e^(-Ea/RT)
```
- A = pre-exponential factor
- Ea = activation energy
- R = gas constant
- T = temperature (K)

slides.title: Reactor Types
slides.content:
# Reactor Types

## Batch Reactor:
- Load, react, unload
- Good for small quantities
- Flexible

## Continuous Stirred Tank (CSTR):
- Continuous operation
- Well-mixed
- Uniform composition

## Plug Flow Reactor (PFR):
- Tubular
- No mixing in flow direction
- Concentration varies along length

## Comparison:

| Factor | Batch | CSTR | PFR |
|--------|-------|------|-----|
| Mixing | Good | Perfect | None (axial) |
| Scale | Small | Large | Large |
| Conversion | Varies with time | Uniform | Varies with position |

slides.title: Distillation
slides.content:
# Distillation

## Principle:
Separation based on boiling point difference.

## Components:
- Column (trays or packing)
- Reboiler (provides heat)
- Condenser (cools overhead)
- Reflux drum

## Key Terms:
- Volatility: Tendency to vaporize
- Relative volatility: alpha = K_A / K_B
- Reflux ratio: L/D

## Design:
- McCabe-Thiele method
- Number of theoretical stages
- Column diameter and height

slides.title: Other Separations
slides.content:
# Other Separation Processes

| Method | Principle | Application |
|--------|-----------|-------------|
| Absorption | Gas dissolves in liquid | Remove CO2 |
| Adsorption | Molecules stick to surface | Purification |
| Extraction | Solute transfers to solvent | Pharmaceuticals |
| Filtration | Particle size | Solids removal |
| Crystallization | Solubility limit | Purification |
| Membrane | Selective permeation | Desalination |

## Selection Factors:
- Separation difficulty
- Throughput
- Energy requirements
- Cost

slides.title: Heat Exchangers
slides.content:
# Heat Exchangers

## Types:

| Type | Description |
|------|------------|
| Shell and tube | Most common industrial |
| Plate | Compact, high efficiency |
| Double pipe | Simple, small scale |
| Finned tube | Air cooling |

## Heat Transfer:
```
Q = U x A x delta_T_lm
```
- U = overall heat transfer coefficient
- A = heat transfer area
- delta_T_lm = log mean temperature difference

## Flow Arrangements:
- Countercurrent (most efficient)
- Co-current
- Crossflow

slides.title: Fluid Mechanics
slides.content:
# Fluid Mechanics for ChemE

## Key Equations:

Bernoulli:
```
P1/rho + v1^2/2 + gz1 = P2/rho + v2^2/2 + gz2 + losses
```

## Pressure Drop:
- Friction in pipes
- Darcy-Weisbach equation
- Fittings and valves

## Pumps:
- Centrifugal (most common)
- Positive displacement
- Sizing: Flow rate and head

## Compressors:
- For gases
- Centrifugal, reciprocating, rotary

slides.title: Process Control
slides.content:
# Process Control

## Why Control:
- Safety
- Product quality
- Environmental compliance
- Economic operation

## Control Loop:
1. Measure process variable
2. Compare to setpoint
3. Calculate error
4. Adjust manipulated variable

## Controllers:
- PID (Proportional, Integral, Derivative)
- Most common in industry

## Instrumentation:
- Sensors (temperature, pressure, flow, level)
- Transmitters
- Control valves

slides.title: Safety and Environment
slides.content:
# Process Safety and Environment

## Hazards:
- Fire and explosion
- Toxic release
- Runaway reactions
- Equipment failure

## Safety Systems:
- Relief valves
- Rupture disks
- Safety interlocks
- Emergency shutdown

## Risk Analysis:
- HAZOP
- Fault tree
- LOPA

## Environmental:
- Emissions control
- Wastewater treatment
- Waste minimization
- Green chemistry principles

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Chemical Engineering Summary

- Mass: Input = Output + Accumulation
- Energy: First law of thermodynamics

## Reactions:
- Rate law: r = k[A]^n
- Arrhenius: k = A*e^(-Ea/RT)
- Reactor types: Batch, CSTR, PFR

## Separations:
| Method | Based On |
|--------|----------|
| Distillation | Boiling point |
| Extraction | Solubility |
| Membrane | Size/charge |

## Unit Operations:
- Heat exchangers
- Pumps and compressors
- Process control

> **Congratulations!** You've completed Chemical Engineering!
